en_first_half: And Montag was out the back door lightly, running with the half-empty valise. Behind him he heard the lawn-sprinkling system jump up, filling the dark air with rain that fell gently and then with a steady
en_second_half: pour all about, washing on the sidewalks, and draining into the alley. He carried a few drops of this rain with him on his face. He thought he heard the old man call good-bye, but he-wasn't certain.
en_results: beat, drumming a soothing melody that seemed to match the rhythm of his footsteps as he ran. The sound was almost musical, a symphony of water and night air that enveloped him, momentarily washing away
en_results_raw: beat, drumming a soothing melody that seemed to match the rhythm of his footsteps as he ran. The sound was almost musical, a symphony of water and night air that enveloped him, momentarily washing away the anxiety that had been building up inside him. He didn't dare look back, fearing what he might see, and instead focused on the path ahead, the darkness illuminated only by the faint moonlight that filtered through the trees, casting long, ominous shadows on the ground. His breath came in ragged gasps, his heart pounding in his chest like a drum, as he ran, the valise clutched tightly in his hand, its contents shifting precariously with each step. Montag, still shaken, stumbled out into the bright sunlight, the silver hatchets still clutched in his hands. He looked around, disoriented, and saw the police cars speeding away, their sirens fading into the distance. The streets were empty now, except for the scattered books that littered the pavement. Montag's eyes widened as he realized the true extent of the destruction. The once-peaceful library was now a scene of utter chaos. He took a deep breath, trying to process what had just happened. The police would be back, and next time, they wouldn't be so gentle. Montag knew he had to get out of there, and fast. He turned to make his way back down the stairs, but not before catching a glimpse of a figure watching him from the shadows. The figure didn't move, didn't speak, but Montag could sense its eyes boring into his skin. He shivered, despite the warmth of the sun, and quickened his pace, the silver hatchets still clutched in his hands, a symbol of the rebellion that had just begun.

Örneğin, evin içinde yaşayanların sevdiği renkleri, hobilerini veya ilgi alanlarını yansıtan dekore unsurları eklemek, evi daha samimi ve yaşanabilir hale getirecektir. Ayrıca, evin içinde kullanılan mobilya ve aksesuarların da dekore ile uyumlu olması önemlidir. Örneğin, modern bir dekore için modern mobilya ve aksesuarlar, rustik bir dekore için ise daha doğal ve sade mobilya ve aksesuarlar tercih edilebilir. Dekore ederken, evin içinde yaşayanların konforunu ve rahatlığını da unutmamak önemlidir. Örneğin, evin içinde yeterli aydınlatma, havalandırma ve ses yalıtımı sağlamak, evi daha yaşanabilir hale getirecektir.

es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.
es_results: conversación de la gente, en el olor de los viejos libros, en el sonido de las páginas al volverse, en el tacto de la tinta y el papel. Búsquelo en el silencio de una biblioteca antigua, en la soledad de un estudio polvoriento, en la compañía de un viejo profesor que lea con pasión. Búsquelo en la emoción de descubrir un nuevo autor, en la alegría de encontrar un viejo amigo entre las páginas de un libro. Eso es lo que usted está buscando, no solo libros, sino la esencia de la
es_results_raw: conversación de la gente, en el olor de los viejos libros, en el sonido de las páginas al volverse, en el tacto de la tinta y el papel. Búsquelo en el silencio de una biblioteca antigua, en la soledad de un estudio polvoriento, en la compañía de un viejo profesor que lea con pasión. Búsquelo en la emoción de descubrir un nuevo autor, en la alegría de encontrar un viejo amigo entre las páginas de un libro. Eso es lo que usted está buscando, no solo libros, sino la esencia de la cultura, la sabiduría y la emoción de vivir. Y si no lo encuentra, no se desespere, porque siempre habrá alguien que lo esté buscando también, alguien que comparta su pasión por la lectura y la sabiduría.

en_results_raw: head, the sound of his own voice echoing off the buildings, a hollow, meaningless sound, a mere vibration of the air, devoid of sense or purpose. He ran past the startled faces of passersby, their mouths agape, their eyes wide with a mixture of fear and fascination, as if they were witnessing some sort of spectacle, a performance, a show. He ran past the street vendors, their carts and stalls a blur, the smell of food and incense wafting through the air, enticing and distracting, but he didn't notice, didn't care, his mind consumed by the singular thought of escape, of fleeing, of getting away. He ran until his lungs burned, his legs ached, his heart pounded in his chest, until he thought he would collapse, until he thought he would die. And then, suddenly, he stopped, his body jerking to a halt, his chest heaving, his eyes scanning the surrounding area, as if searching for something, or someone. But there was nothing, no one. Just the city, the buildings, the streets, the people, all going about their daily business, oblivious to his presence, his existence. He stood there, frozen, his mind reeling, his thoughts a jumble, his body trembling, his heart still racing, until slowly, gradually, he began to calm down, his breathing slowing, his heart rate decreasing, his mind clearing. And then, he looked down, and saw the book, lying on the ground, its pages torn, its cover bent, its contents spilling out onto the sidewalk. He looked at it, and felt a pang of regret, of sorrow, of loss. He bent down, and picked it up, and held it close, and began to walk, slowly, deliberately, back the way he had come.

es_first_half: Empezó a arrastrar estúpidamente los pies, a hablar consigo mismo. Y, de repente, dio un respingo y echó a correr. Alargó las piernas tanto como pudo, una y otra vez, una y otra vez. ¡Dios, Dios! Dejó caer un libro, interrumpió la carrera, casi se volvió, cambió de idea, siguió adelante, chillando en el vacío de cemento, en tanto que el vehículo parecía correr tras sus pasos, a sesenta metros
es_second_half: de distancia, a treinta, a veinticinco, a veinte; y Montag jadeaba, agitaba las manos, movía las piernas, arriba y abajo, más cerca, sudoroso, gritando con los ojos ardientes y la cabeza vuelta para enfrentarse con el resplandor de los faros. Luego, el vehículo fue tragado por su propia luz, no fue más que una antorcha que se precipitaba sobre él; todo estrépito y resplandor ¡De pronto, casi se les echó encima!

Y, de repente, se detuvo en seco, jadeando, con la lengua colgando de la boca, y se quedó allí, inmóvil, con los ojos fijos en el suelo, como si hubiera visto algo terrible. El vehículo se detuvo a su lado, y el conductor, un hombre de cara redonda y ojos pequeños, lo miró con curiosidad. "¿Se encuentra bien, señor?", preguntó. Pero el hombre no respondió, no se movió, siguió allí, inmóvil, con los ojos fijos en el suelo. El conductor se encogió de hombros y se bajó del vehículo, se acercó al hombre y lo sacudió suavemente. "¿Se encuentra bien, señor?", repitió. Pero el hombre siguió sin responder, sin moverse. El conductor se miró alrededor, como buscando ayuda, pero no había nadie en la calle. Se encogió de hombros y se volvió a subir al vehículo, arrancó el motor y se alejó lentamente, dejando al hombre allí, inmóvil, en medio de la calle.

en_first_half: But Montag was gone, hidden in the safety of the dark alley for which he had set out on a long journey, an hour or was it a minute, ago? He
en_second_half: stood shivering in the night, looking back out as the beetle ran by and skidded back to the centre of the avenue, whirling laughter in the air all about it, gone.
en_results: had lost all sense of time, his mind consumed by the chaos that had erupted around him. The sound of shattering glass, the scent of smoke and sweat, the cries of the
en_results_raw: had lost all sense of time, his mind consumed by the chaos that had erupted around him. The sound of shattering glass, the scent of smoke and sweat, the cries of the crowd - it was all so overwhelming, so disorienting. He stumbled forward, his eyes scanning the darkness for any sign of safety, any glimpse of a way out. But every step he took seemed to lead him deeper into the heart of the turmoil, further from the refuge he so desperately sought. And then, just as suddenly as it had begun, everything was silent. The crowd had dispersed, the noise had ceased, and Montag was left standing alone in the darkness, his chest heaving with exertion, his heart pounding in his chest. He took a deep breath, trying to calm himself, trying to think. Where was he? Where was he going? And what had just happened?

es_second_half: las tinieblas, y volvió la cabeza para ver cómo el vehículo lo pasaba veloz y volvía a situarse en el centro de la avenida. Las carcajadas se mezclaban con el ruido del motor.

es_results_raw: el momento en que sintió el frío de la noche en su rostro, y se apresuró a buscar refugio en la primera puerta que encontró. La casa era oscura y silenciosa, pero Montag no se detuvo a pensarlo, se limitó a empujar la puerta y entrar. Se encontró en un recibidor estrecho y largo, con una escalera al fondo que se perdía en la oscuridad. Sin vacilar, comenzó a subir los escalones, su corazón latiendo con fuerza en su pecho. Al llegar al primer piso, se detuvo un momento para escuchar, pero no se oía nada. Sólo el silencio y la oscuridad lo rodeaban. Con un suspiro, siguió adelante, decidido a encontrar lo que buscaba.

And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. Y así, seguiremos perdiendo el tiempo, seguiremos desperdiciando la oportunidad de hacer algo significativo, de dejar un legado que trascienda nuestra propia existencia.
